text: Gatekeepers of Law: Inside the Westlaw and LexisNexis Duopoly Ever since a spate of mergers in the 1990s, Westlaw and LexisNexis have dominated legal research. And that might be why searching legal cases is so costly, even in the age of AI. Introduction Hi there! My name is Tom Blakely, I'm a federal judicial law clerk and attorney. I previously worked in big law and the United States Department of Justice. You might remember me from last year, when I wrote about the US v. Google ad tech antitrust trial at Big Tech on Trial . I'm excited to be writing a guest piece for BIG, this time on a particular competition problem I (and nearly every lawyer) deals with on a daily basis: the Lexis/Westlaw duopoly. The law in America does not belong to lawyers, it belongs to all of us. As citizens, we must be able to read the law, understand it, obey it, and bring complaints against those who wrong us. That is the basis for a coherent political order, and why the rule of law is such a foundational aspect of a democratic system. Moreover, it would be hard to find a technological era more suited to the democratization of law than the one we're in today. The computer lets anyone query instantly, the internet lets anyone do it from anywhere, and generative artificial intelligence can decipher and explain complex legal questions if it has access to credible databases. And yet, today, two powerful companies dominate and restrain access to key aspects of our legal order, from case opinions to legislative history. To give you a sense of what I mean, Lexis, one of two dominant legal research platforms, charges up to $469 for a single search. That's the equivalent of a Google query, for almost $500. Moreover, beyond LexisNexis and its rival Westlaw, the Federal judiciary itself has used its privileged position to charge high fees for court records that should be available to all. Today, the law is hidden behind paywalls. But it wasn't always this way. In this piece, I'm going to explain how and why America keeps the law from its citizens, and what we can do about it. text: Ziggurats as Power Towers: Architecture That Trains Obedience The first Mesopotamian cities did not emerge as neutral containers for human life; they were engineered systems that concentrated people, goods, and authority into forms that could be managed at scale. The first Mesopotamian cities did not emerge as neutral containers for human life; they were engineered systems that concentrated people, goods, and authority into forms that could be managed at scale. In southern Mesopotamia, especially in the Uruk and Early Dynastic periods, temples were central to that engineering. They were not only sites of worship but institutional hubs where storage, labor organization, craft production, land management, and adjudication converged, producing a durable urban hierarchy that could be experienced as both practical and sacred. The visual culture of early cities belongs inside this institutional story. Ziggurats, votive statues, cylinder seals, and administrative tablets were not separate categories of religious art, political art, or economic artifacts; they were interlocking technologies that made power legible, repeatable, and difficult to refuse. The temple precinct became a place where the divine was staged, but also where dependencies were created, recorded, and normalized through objects that fused belief with infrastructure. (The Met, Uruk: The First City; Pollock; Postgate) Temple institutions shaped the first cities by turning basic necessities into administrable flows. Urban growth demanded dependable routines. Grain must be stored, counted, milled, and distributed; animals must be herded, culled, and accounted for; textiles must be produced in predictable quantities; and labor must be scheduled across planting, harvesting, construction, and maintenance. In Mesopotamian lowland ecology, where large-scale irrigation and coordinated maintenance could make the difference between abundance and crisis, institutional capacity carried ideological weight. Temples concentrated surplus in storehouses and mobilized it through redistribution, which meant that economic survival increasingly passed through institutional hands. text: Shiny New Stats Toys Can't Wrest Causation From Correlational Data And it's harming social science to keep trying. If there's one thing a social scientist with a pet theory hates to hear more than "correlation doesn't equal causation", I don't know what it is 1 . We've long understood that well-designed and well-controlled randomized experiments are the best (and perhaps only) means of making causal conclusions from behavioral data 2 . Unfortunately, both ethics and convenience often prevent us from doing those randomized, controlled experiments. As such, for decades…really, as long as we've had inferential statistics…statisticians 3 have been trying to come up with new ways to wrest causation from correlational data. The result has been disaster for science communication. Indeed, even the earliest regression equations…fascinatingly dating even to the late 19 th century studies of " pauperism "…were used to argue for causation from correlational data. The argument then seems to be that, if a correlation persisted after controlling for theoretically relevant controls, than that persisting correlation must be causal. This, of course, made a lot of assumptions about the data, not only its reliability, but also that all theoretical controls could be identified and measured. Most of us today don't seriously think that basic regression equations allow us to make causal inferences. But some scholars simply move on to the next shiny toy arguing, "no, seriously, ok, all those other approaches failed, sure, but THIS one, THIS one will let us assert causality from correlational data." And, of course, just like the attempts with regressions…they fail. Secrets of Grimoire Manor is a reader-supported publication. Arizona's lawmakers are starting to take AI legislation seriously, and not a moment too soon. GOP lawmakers in the state House announced this week the creation of the AI and Innovation Committee, headed by Rep. Justin Wilmeth. It's not clear yet exactly what legislation the committee hopes to advance, but lawmakers appeared to grasp how important AI regulations will be in the coming years. "With the creation of the AI and Innovation Committee, the legislature is signaling that policymakers are evaluating their role in the future of Arizona: creating high-skill jobs, attracting new investment, and strengthening existing industries from semiconductors to healthcare." Wilmeth said he wants the committee to be a "forum where experts, industry leaders, and members of the public can share their perspectives, knowledge, and concerns so we can create informed and effective legislation." text: The One Simple Thing That Makes the U.S. Economy Unmanageable We used to be able to answer the question "How much does that cost?" But prices in America are not only high, but increasingly hidden. Fortunately, there's pushback. In 1956, CBS launched a new game show, The Price Is Right, in its daytime schedule. Contestants were presented with various objects, and the one who guessed closest to the actual retail price would win. The Price Is Right became the longest running game show in American history, because it spoke to a very casual yet deceptively important social question: How much does it cost? There's an important political assumption behind that question, which is that every retail item has one single price. And any buyer anywhere in America can pay that price to acquire it. Americans might have had different amounts of money, but they were all equal in that they paid the same amount for the same good. While a single price in a market might seem a natural state of affairs, and economists love presenting simple supply and demand curves assuming as much, there's nothing natural about it. In fact, a dense network of laws and norms created the notion of a single price for all buyers and sellers in a market, aka, The Price Is Right society. We no longer live in such a society, because the legal framework behind a single public price for an item has fallen apart. There are many examples, but the easiest way to understand this change is to look at health care markets, where hiding prices, and the consequences thereof, is most advanced. There Are No Real Prices In Health Care A few days ago, Hunterbrook, a short-seller funded media outfit, released an investigative report showing what looks like a multi-billion dollar money laundering operation by the three largest health insurance companies. The allegation is that CVS, UnitedHealth Group, and Cigna are supposed to negotiate with pharmaceutical companies for lower drug prices for their patients. But instead, they collude with those pharmaceutical companies to force higher drug prices, and split the profits with them. It's not a new charge. text: Analytics Philosophy: Low Ceilings and Bottomless Floors What to make of counterintuitive findings in the world of soccer analytics One of the issues with the general uptake of soccer analytics across the spectrum of stakeholders is the struggle with certain counterintuitive claims. These claims often defy what many people intuitively understand about the game. They're also a little bit exaggerated in order to get attention, but at the core point to an important truth. I'm not going to spend too much time on establishing these claims are true; that's done better elsewhere. Thanks for reading 500 Words Per 90! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Instead, I'm going to look at two claims on a philosophical level and why the general perception (what most people call "the eye test") and the numbers don't seem to agree. There is something that these two claims have in common; a bottomless individual skill floor and a fairly low ceiling at the highest level. Claim 1: Coaching doesn't matter The relative impact of coaching and whether or not a certain individual is a "good" coach or not takes up a massive amount of media space. A few months into every season, the carousel starts spinning as underperforming coaches are fired and new ones are brought on. At the same time, there's not a lot of evidence that coaches can do all that much to impact the game. So what are the essential functions of a coach? text: A reply to critics on American oil and gas Warning: This is very long because I'm trying to be thorough. On December 18, I published an op-ed in the New York Times arguing that Democrats should approach the American oil and gas industry more like successful center-left coalitions in Norway, Canada, and Mexico do with their own fossil fuel industries. That is to say, broadly speaking, that Democrats should invest money and political capital in trying to reduce consumption of fossil fuels - especially by promoting technological changes that move the needle on global emissions - rather than in trying to stifle domestic production. The argument is in part political. Mark Carney and Claudia Sheinbaum have totally different political styles, but neither thinks it would be viable to win elections in resource-rich countries while opposing their countries' natural resource industries. Jared Polis, Michelle Lujan Grisham, and Josh Shapiro are the governors of the three blue states where fossil fuel extraction is most economically important, and they all support their states' fossil fuel industries. And no one's going to win in redder states like Ohio, Alaska, and Texas with a stance that's to the left of Democrats in Colorado, New Mexico, and Pennsylvania. And since there's no path to a Senate majority that doesn't involve winning those redder states, the national party may as well stop banging its head against the wall of an impossible supply-side agenda and focus on what it can achieve. But my argument is also substantive. I genuinely think that a prudent approach to managing American fossil fuel resources is preferable to treating the oil and gas industry like cigarette manufacturers. Burning fossil fuels creates significant amounts of pollution, both particulates and greenhouse gases. text: Hey, What Are All These Books Doing To Us? And is everything about to change? Hello again! Today's the last day of the end-of-season offer for Everything Is Amazing - and it's time to explain what's coming for paid subscribers in the upcoming season. If I may, I'd like to introduce you to a book that's very special to me. Every year at this time (it's my birthday today), I like to sit by a window and read it for a while, to remind myself how ludicrously subjective the term "old" is. The spine crackles as you open it, and the pages have a musty scent that's so complicated it could only be the product of decades of moving through the world, soaking up the smells of so many different rooms and their furnishings and occupants, until it's become a piece of 20th-Century olfactory archaeology. text: We Must Prepare For Peace, Not War. If peace requires preparation for war, then: mistrust is rational, suspicion is intelligent, escalation is responsible "Si vis pacem, para bellum" : a sentence that poisoned the idea of peace " If you want peace, prepare for war " sounds prudent. Almost wise. That's precisely why it has been so destructive. This phrase did three deep things to the human mind : It redefined peace as an absence of attack , not a shared condition. Peace ceased to be something built together and became something imposed through fear . You are "at peace" not because interests are aligned, but because the other side is afraid to move. That is not peace. That is a truce under threat. It normalized permanent hostility by creating a world where every actor must assume bad faith , because failing to do so is framed as naïveté or weakness. Over time, this becomes self-fulfilling: everyone behaves aggressively because everyone expects aggression. It doesn't prevent war. It makes war structurally inevitable . It fused security with domination. From Rome to modern empires, "para bellum" justified arms races, military–industrial complexes, proxy wars, deterrence doctrines that accept mass civilian death as a "cost"… Security stopped being about safety and became about superiority . The Cold War is the clearest example: humanity survived not because the paradigm worked, but because we got lucky - repeatedly. Deterrence did not create peace; it created suspended catastrophe . Negotiation became secondary, even suspicious. Talking was something you did after weapons were ready, not instead of them. As a result, diplomats lost influence, military logic dominated political thinking and compromise became synonymous with weakness. Trillions were spent on preparing for destruction instead of climate resilience, global health, education, shared technological advancement… The tragedy is not just moral - it's civilizational misallocation . We have been trying to poison it with pills or hide it with suppressants. But HIV is a physical object. It has mass, it has a size (roughly 120 nanometers), and crucial to this design-it has a specific electrical charge. If it's a physical object, it can be moved. If it can be moved, it can be removed. Every biological particle-a red blood cell, a T-cell, and the HIV virus itself-has a unique "dielectric signature." It vibrates and moves differently when hit with specific electrical frequencies. text: Two Weeks into Iran‚Äôs Protest Wave: A New Phase Anti-regime protests in Iran have now lasted for two weeks, and in recent days they appear to have entered a new phase. Anti-regime protests in Iran have now lasted for two weeks, and in recent days they appear to have entered a new phase. In my previous post , published on the fifth day, I reflected on the initial geography of unrest and compared it with Iran's earlier protest waves. The current episode began with shopkeepers in Tehran's Grand Bazaar, where slogans supporting the Pahlavi monarchy were also heard. Over the following days, protests spread primarily to Persian-speaking districts as well as Lor and Caspian areas. Meanwhile, Kurdish, Azeri, Baluchi, Arab, and Sunni-majority districts were largely absent or only weakly represented during the initial phase-consistent with their limited sympathy for monarchist slogans and with longer-standing political tensions between monarchist currents and marginalized ethnolinguistic constituencies. Thanks for reading Popular Politics, Unbound! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Some commentators quickly framed the protests as driven mainly by economic deprivation. And indeed, from Lor districts, protests did spread into deprived Kurdish areas of Ilam, such as Abdanan, Ilam, and Malekshahi. But the economic explanation alone cannot account for the early geography of the unrest. Other deeply impoverished regions-most notably in Sistan and Baluchestan-did not join the protests in the initial phase. What mattered, in addition to deprivation, was ethnic identity as well as proximity to early protest sites. As scholars of revolutions and social movements have long emphasized, once a contentious episode begins, diffusion dynamics can accelerate participation beyond what structural conditions alone would predict-through inspiration, shared emotions, and the rapid spread of information. text: LLM poetry and the "greatness" question Experiments by Gwern and Mercor I have been looking at the ability of large language models (LLMs) to write poetry for more than five years . With every new model, the technical abilities improve: pro models can produce lines and stanzas, handle rhyme and meter, and create surprising and witty turns of phrase, produce impressive metaphors. Technique is not the problem. Does any LLM output rise to the level of good poetry, or even great poetry? It's a different question than studies about favorable ratings ask. I'm interested in greatness, what it is, and can LLMs get there. My definition of "great" poetry, which I've used over thirty years of reading, teaching, and writing poetry, is simple: a great poem is both particular and universal. A great poem is "about" a specific person or moment embedded in a particular culture, composed in such a way that it reaches across time and distance to resonate with readers outside that culture. Poets work inside an historical network of existing poems. A new poem resonates when it activates prior reading in the mind of the reader. Lines and images from older work resonate with each other and with new work. That resonance is the mechanism by which the particular becomes universal. LLMs are trained on existing texts. LLMs have in their training data most of the digitized poetry in existence; their output tends to reflect patterns in that data. A model asked to write a poem about grief will draw upon images and phrasings about grief in earlier poems. ( Primer on vector embeddings.) But LLMs do not yet, at this writing, have culture. Without culture, I'm not sure there can be great poetry. Gwern If anyone can crack this nut, it is my favorite thinker on how exactly LLMs and poetry work: Gwern . text: How to Turn Your Resume Into a Narrative Alexandra Aileru, career counselor Courtesy of Alexandra Aileru A lot of aspiring and early career journalists struggle with crafting a resume. But it might help if you thought of it less as a collection of job titles and more like an alternative-story form for the narrative of your career. We talked with career counselor Alexandra Aileru, founder of Confident Career Switch, about resumes. What is the purpose of a resume? The purpose of a resume is to clearly and professionally communicate the value you bring, using past experiences, measurable outcomes, and honed skills as evidence. It allows recruiters and hiring managers to quickly decide whether to begin or continue a conversation with you. A strong resume translates your experience into language the employer understands, especially if you have a non-linear or early-career background. What is the biggest mistake you see people make with resumes? The biggest mistake is a weak or unclear career narrative. Many people list roles without first reviewing their achievements, skills, and values, then selecting what is most relevant to the role they're applying for. When the story isn't clear, hiring managers are forced to guess-and that usually ends the conversation. Never assume an employer understands your background; your resume should explain it clearly to someone encountering it for the first time. How are companies using AI to read resumes? How should applicants respond? Companies use AI to scan resumes for relevant keywords, skills, and patterns, which means applicants need to optimize for both technology and humans. Use role-specific language, simple formatting, and measurable outcomes, ideally following a structure such as what you did, the impact (with metrics), and how you did it. Keywords should always be used accurately and in context, or they will be flagged later in screening or interviews. For early-career students with little experience, what should go on a resume? The Goal is to Boost the Construction Industry Venezuela holds some of the world's largest proven oil reserves, primarily located in the Orinoco Belt. On paper, this seems like a recipe for enormous revenue. However, the reality is far more complex. The majority of Venezuelan crude is heavy or extra-heavy oil , characterized by high viscosity, elevated sulfur content, and significant amounts of metals such as nickel and vanadium. These properties make it difficult and expensive to refine into conventional fuels like gasoline or diesel, limiting its attractiveness for traditional petroleum markets. Refining heavy crude requires advanced technology and substantial capital investment. Processes such as coking, hydrocracking, and hydrogenation are necessary to convert heavy fractions into lighter, saleable fuels. Setting up such facilities is not only costly-often running into billions of dollars-but also technically demanding. Additionally, Venezuelan political instability and international sanctions introduce further financial and operational risks. For many foreign investors, these factors make deep refining ventures economically unattractive, especially when simpler and safer alternatives exist. Thanks for reading Sherlock's Substack! text: How RFK Jr. Cherry Picks Science When ‚Äúinsufficient data‚Äù gets twisted into ‚Äúvaccines don‚Äôt work‚Äù One of the most effective rhetorical tricks in modern health misinformation isn't inventing fake studies, it's misusing real ones. In a recent interview with CBS News , Robert F. Kennedy Jr. claims that a Cochrane review shows the flu vaccine does not reduce the risk of severe disease in children. On its face, that sounds authoritative. Cochrane is widely respected. However, when you look closely, what RFK Jr. is doing isn't evidence-based critique, it's selective framing designed to turn "absence of data" into "proof of failure." The Cochrane Collaboration review he's referring to does not conclude that flu vaccines fail to prevent severe disease in children. What it actually says is far less sensational: randomized controlled trials were not designed or powered to measure rare outcomes like hospitalization, ICU admission, or death in otherwise healthy children. That's not a dismissal of vaccine benefit; it's a basic statistical reality. When severe outcomes are uncommon, even very effective interventions won't show statistically significant differences in trials that enroll a few thousand participants. Cochrane is transparent about this limitation. RFK Jr. strips that nuance away. This is the pattern: take a cautious methodological statement and rebrand it as a negative finding. "We do not have sufficient data to measure X" becomes "there is no evidence for X." Those are not equivalent statements, and anyone trained in clinical research knows it. The former invites further study and broader evidence synthesis. The latter is a rhetorical endpoint designed to imply failure where none has been demonstrated. Crucially, Cochrane reviews are not meant to be the sole arbiter of public health policy. text: The AI water issue is fake On the national, local, and personal level AI data centers use water. Like any other industry that uses water, they require careful planning. If an electric car factory opens near you, that factory may use just as much water as a data center . The factory also requires careful planning. But the idea that either the factory or AI is using an inordinate amount of water that merits any kind of boycott or national attention as a unique serious environmental issue is innumerate. Individual data centers can sometimes stress local water systems in the way other industries do, but when you use AI, you are not contributing to a significant problem for water management compared to most other things you do in your day to day life. On the national, local, and personal level, AI is barely using any water, and unless it grows 50 times faster than forecasts predict, this won't change. I'm writing from an American context and don't know as much about other countries. But at least in America, the numbers are clear and decisive. text: Genuine Digital Security at the Network Level Has Always Been Available The prevailing cybersecurity landscape is built on a fundamental contradiction: it thrives on managing breaches rather than preventing them. The prevailing cybersecurity landscape is built on a fundamental contradiction: it thrives on managing breaches rather than preventing them. Billions of dollars flow annually into products and services designed to detect, respond, and mitigate the damage caused by cybersecurity failures. This entrenched model accepts breaches as inevitable, focusing on risk management instead of genuine security. The result is an industry that perpetuates insecurity while claiming to safeguard against it. At the core of this systemic failure lies a critical flaw in how identity and authentication are understood. Current public-access authentication methods rely primarily on data, passwords, tokens, biometric records, that serve as proxies for identity. These credentials are transmitted, stored, and verified repeatedly, creating an expansive attack surface vulnerable to theft, replication, and misuse. Authentication in this context does not confirm the actual existence of the person claiming an identity but rather verifies possession of data associated with that identity. This distinction is crucial and often overlooked. The failure to incorporate existence as a factor in authentication means that systems operate on assumptions: that credentials are accurate, legitimate, and possessed by the rightful user. These assumptions are inherently fragile. Credentials can be stolen, guessed, or forged; biometric data can be duplicated or spoofed; and tokens can be intercepted. Consequently, identity theft, unauthorized access, and breaches caused by weak authentication persist as endemic problems. A transformative approach to digital security demands a redefinition of authentication itself. Instead of verifying identity through data, security must verify the actual, physical presence of the user in real time. text: The Leadership Shift No One Explains to New EMs What "being technical" means when you're no longer the one writing the code When new Engineering Managers look up at Directors, VPs, and CTOs, they often feel a quiet contradiction. On one hand, they're told: "As you grow, you need to think more systemically." On the other, the industry celebrates: "Very senior leaders who are still deeply technical." If you're a new EM, this creates an uncomfortable question: Should I stay close to the code to remain credible? Or step back and risk becoming vague, generic, or irrelevant? This post is an attempt to resolve that tension. It's based on patterns I've seen in mid-to-large engineering organisations. It is not universal truth. And it absolutely breaks down in some contexts, which I'll name explicitly. First, a clarification This is not an argument that senior leaders shouldn't be technical. And it is not a defence of managers who hide behind words like "strategy" or "systems" to excuse technical decay. Those people exist. They are harmful. And they're not what this article is describing. What is real - and often misunderstood - is that the nature of technical work changes as scope increases . If that distinction isn't clear, the rest of this doesn't land. Scope: when this applies - and when it doesn't This framing generally applies when: You're in a mid-size or large org (roughly 40+ engineers) There are Staff+ engineers owning deep technical decisions The work involves coordination, trade-offs, and long-term constraints It breaks down when: You're in a 10–20 person startup Leaders must code to keep the company alive There is no meaningful separation between execution and system design If you're early-stage: keep coding. A lot of this won't help you yet. text: Democrats need a theory of power, but democracies need a theory of accountability No, the Trump administration is not a model for how to get things done We are at a crucial, once-in-a-century moment for American governance. Those on the right are, whether they admit it or not, aligning themselves with an increasingly authoritarian model of governance under Trump. Even before Trump's second term began, many progressive thinkers were forming their own criticisms of public institutions as too tied down by procedural constraints to actually realize their goals. I don't know which vision will win, or what the future of American governance will look like, but the safest bet is that it will look significantly different from the past. This December, I will match any new paid subscriptions to Can We Still Govern? with an equivalent gift to Give Directly , so consider subscribing! The combination of Trumpist authoritarianism and the many flavors of abundance sit uncomfortably together. A reasonable claim is that in the spaces where progressives still hold institutional power, they need to use it better, as well as plan for how to use federal power when they regain it. An unreasonable claim is that Trump is teaching Democrats how to govern. text: Solo Card Games and Decision Making The underlying complexity of cards and how to use them to create dynamic decisions for players. The Two Basic Levers of a Combat-based Solo Card Game If you're playing a game where you build a deck of cards and do combat, the two levers that are pulled are your ability to deal damage and your ability to mitigate damage dealt to you. Status effects or cards that augment the amount of cards used are variations of that concept (making an enemy deal less damage = damage mitigation/making yourself deal more damage = increasing ability to deal damage/increasing the number of cards you can play = greater degree of choices in mitigating damage or dealing damage). The Two Levers of any Card Game. The interesting complexities of a card game, I'd argue, comes from what decisions are made outside of the card playing. Scenario One - A Card Game with Limited Complexity You have one opponent and this opponent has 5 Health. The opponent is hitting you for 5 Health worth of damage. You draw 5 Cards. You can play any 3 of the 5 Cards. 2 of these cards deal 1 point of damage. 2 other cards deal 2 points of damage. The final card will Block 5 points of damage. If you can only play 3 Cards, your decision is streamlined into the most obvious and efficient course of action: you play two cards that deal 2 points of damage each and one card that deals 1 point of damage to defeat your opponent. This is a card game at its most basic. A game like this, where your cards are variations of dealing and blocking damage and the chance of succeeding or failing on a given turn is based on the luck of the draw does not lead to any compelling decisions or complex strategy. Even introducing a mechanic like a "mulligan" where you can discard your cards and draw an equal number of cards does little to add to the complexity of the game. You play the cards you're dealt and with a mulligan, you're fishing for the most optimal set of cards in your deck. Foreign Interference and the Alberta Prosperity Project JASON FRANSON/THE CANADIAN PRESS When does a separatist movement become a threat to Canada's national security? Thanks for reading! People are asking how it can possibly be that the very same individuals who are leading the separatist movement can also be three meetings deep into a relationship with senior officials of the Trump Administration in Washington, with a fourth scheduled for this month. Treason. Sedition. Traitorous. These are words that are ricocheting around the radio talk shows, and the social media channels. In the aftermath of the US's move on Venezuela people are genuinely concerned that Canada could also be "on the menu." There is a growing recognition that resource imperialism has become the basic orienting principle of US grand strategy. And that Canada, as a resource rich, and militarily poor nation has become exceptionally vulnerable to it. A sovereignty referendum engineered by a group known as the Alberta Prosperity Project at a time like this takes on exceptional, existential risk to Canada's continuance as a sovereign nation in the Western Hemisphere. It's important, therefore, to understand where the line between political movement and national security threat is drawn in Canada. It is, as we know, entirely legal in Canada to advocate and campaign in support of a province or territory leaving confederation. This is covered by the Clarity Act , but also by the Charter which protects the rights of citizens to free expression, assembly, and association. Any organic political movement that is based in a genuine desire to achieve an outcome of their design is free to pursue that through whatever lawful means available to them. Foreign interference in such movements however, is where the line between lawful advocacy and dissent crosses into territory that constitutes a threat to Canada's national security. The CSIS Act is clear on this.

text: Marshall McLuhan and the Political Systems We Forgot to Model On Systems and Democratic Strain Over the years, I've come to realize that my affection for Marshall McLuhan is not really about his media theory at all. It's about how he thought about systems. Thanks for reading Sacred Cow BBQ! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. You may have to forgive the love letter that is about to ensue, but I think about this guy's work more than I'd like to admit. Part of McLuhan's mystique (and, let's be honest, also part of why he's sometimes misunderstood) is his writing style. It is dense as hell, often aphoristic, and far more intent on opening questions than closing them. Critics (and plenty of readers) have described it as compelling yet occasionally bewildering, the kind of prose that rewards deep engagement but resists simple exposition. What makes McLuhan worth returning to now, in my opinion, is not nostalgia for mid-century media theory, but the fact that many of our current political failures look less like ideological disagreement (though there's definitely some of that, don't get me wrong!) and more like system-level mismatch. We keep diagnosing content problems in what is actually an environment problem-and that seems like something we really need to get right. McLuhan is usually remembered for some amazing, sticky aphorisms- "the medium is the message," "the global village," and so on, yeah that's him!-but what he actually offered were early theories of how communication systems restructure cognition, coordination, authority, and legitimacy at scale . Long before my field of political science had the language of complex systems, feedback loops, or nonlinear effects, McLuhan was already describing them, he just did it in prose instead of equations or causal diagrams. In an era of algorithmic governance, attention markets, and collapsing institutional trust, that turns out to be unusually useful to reflect on. It's analysis worth paying attention to My fellow pro-growth/progress/abundance Up Wingers in the USA and around the world: Fears that technology will render human labor obsolete are nearly as old as industrial machinery itself. Of course, artificial intelligence has given these anxieties loads of fresh momentum. Will human workers yet go the way of the horse? 1 Goldman Sachs takes that concern seriously - and then largely rejects it. In an illuminating new analysis , "How Concerned Should We Be About a Job Apocalypse?", the bank's economists reiterate their estimate that AI could eventually automate tasks accounting for roughly a quarter of all work hours in the US economy. That exposure is large enough to justify unease. It isn't, however, the same thing as total job destruction of the sort AI doomers often warn. Translating exposure into employment outcomes, Goldman's baseline forecast implies that about 6–7 percent of jobs are displaced over the full AI adoption period. Again, that's meaningful disruption, sure, but hardly mass extinction. 2 GS: "We remain skeptical that unemployment rate increases will be permanent as long as human labor maintains a competitive advantage in certain aspects of production." 3 Subscribe now Here's how GS newly quantifies the labor-market impact: Under its central scenario - AI adoption spread over roughly a decade - the unemployment rate rises by a little over half a percentage point at the peak, equivalent to about one million additional unemployed workers. text: The Wolf Within: What You Need to Know About Lupus From Immune System Malfunction to Modern Treatment When I (Aimee) think about lupus, I don't just think about the science - I think about one of my former students. She was diagnosed with lupus during college, and the disease quickly became a relentless adversary. The usual first-line medication, steroids, that dampen the immune response and often bring relief, barely made a dent. Her lupus was refractory, stubbornly resisting every standard approach. Eventually, her doctors turned to an advanced therapy - a type of immunotherapy that depleted her B cells, the immune cells that play a central role in lupus. At the time, its use was off-label and an unconventional last-ditch measure, but it worked. Slowly, her symptoms eased, and she regained control of her life. What amazes me most is not just the science behind her recovery, but her resilience. Despite years of debilitating illness, she persevered, graduated, and went on to earn her PharmD. She is brilliant, kind, and cheerful - a living testament to the power of perseverance and modern medicine, particularly immunotherapy or treatments that harness the body's own immune system to fight disease. Her story is just one example of how complex lupus can be and why understanding this disease - from the molecular, cellular, and immunological level - matters. So, what exactly is lupus , and why does it sometimes require such aggressive treatments? Let's discuss… What Is Lupus? Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) , commonly known as lupus, is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects millions worldwide. For patients with lupus , the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissues. This can lead to inflammation and damage in multiple organs, including the skin (most notably a distinctive rash across the face), joints, kidneys, reproductive system, intestines, lungs, and even the heart. The other is that the launch of ChatGPT just a few weeks earlier had set in motion a much more significant shift - though the scope of that shift would turn out to be much wider than I guessed at the time. And while the shifting fortunes of our biggest social networks continue to play a critical role in shaping politics, culture, and society, the speed with which generative artificial intelligence systems are improving now seem likely to prove even more significant. Over the next year, I expect to see both trends accelerating: on one hand, a once-in-a-generation realignment in text-based social networking that will further entrench Meta as the biggest player in the space; and on the other, the proliferation of generative AI into every digital surface that we touch, and much of the infrastructure that powers it. Previously, teens could choose less stringent settings. Teen users can't opt out of these new settings. The new restricted status of teen accounts means teens won't be able to see or search for harmful content, even if it is shared by a friend or someone they follow. For example, if a teen's friend had been posting about dieting, those posts will no longer be visible to the teen. However, teens might still see content related to a friend's recovery from an eating disorder. The changes announced today fall broadly into a category of platform tweaks that could be labeled "They weren't doing that already?" There is typically lower variety, weaker selection pressures, and faster environmental change. So the process goes bad, its cultures drift into maladaption, and the civ falls. Our current civ will plausibly suffer this fate, with the added problem that due to modern cultural activism we also have higher rates of internal cultural drift. What does this say about Christianity? Early on it was a small sect competing with many others, and the fact that it won against them suggests that it was unusually adaptive then, at least in that context. Then it took over the Roman Empire and most of Europe, and became securely in pace for millennia. And while securely in place, Christianity substantially changed its character many times. So doesn't my theory suggest that those changes would on average have been maladaptive? Well first notice that most Europeans didn't know much about Christian doctrine re how to live ordinary peasant lives until about 1600 or so. Before then Christianity mainly influenced elites, cities, and larger institutions. Also, there was often lots of competition within Christianity; the cultural evolution problem would only be re cultural features that were imposed on everyone in Christianity, allowing little local deviation. Okay, but Christianity influenced marriage much earlier, from about 1200, promoting monogamy and banning cousins marriage, and that suppressed family clans. Christianity also pushed individualism early on, via consent in marriage and the freedom to write wills, especially donations to the Church. And those wills funded many big monasteries, which slowly took over lots of European land. text: It was not a super flu year Update on flu and covid in England In early December the government and the NHS were issuing dire warnings about super flu , an unprecedented flu wave , and the NHS facing its worst winter since the heights of Covid. Along with many other people watching the data, I couldn't see where these warnings were coming from. Yes, flu season had started early but there was nothing to say - at that time - that it would be worse than previous years. I wrote about it in a December substack post and spoke about it on Sky News . I was worried that this was a bad use of data to scare the public - and striking doctors - into specific actions. A month later, and it's clear that this was not a worse flu year than previous years. Flu admissions peaked in mid December. While the most recent hopsital admission data (to 29 December) shows a small increase in hospitalisations 1 , we are nowhere near 2022 or 2024's peaks, or (so far) overall numbers, even if we get a double peak like we had in 2023/24. Meanwhile, RSV admissions steady but relatively high, and Covid admissions are low and steady. If the government and NHS messaging was about trying to change the public's behaviour (and behaviour might have changed), then I don't think the approach is justified. Getting the public to get to a behaviour through misleading presentation of data from the people and organisations who are meant to be trusted experts is counterproductive and wrong. It's also lazy when you should make the effort to improve the situation through well-established public health measures. This includes improving physical infrastructure such as better ventilation (particularly in health care, school and crowded indoor settings), improving provision (better resourced GPs and hospitals), and better public messaging (e.g. emphasising ventilation and mask wearing alongside hand washing and surface cleaning, or staying home when sick). text: The Epson TV That Printed Photos Epson‚Äôs Livingstation LS47P2 and the convergence that failed At the start of the digital camera boom, Epson decided that the television was the wrong kind of dumb. Screens showed images, but they didn't do anything with them. Epson's solution was not software, networking, or sharing. It was a printer bolted to the bottom of a television. That machine was the Livingstation LS47P2. The idea was blunt and literal: insert a memory card, browse photos on a 47-inch screen, freeze a frame, and print. Epson was trying to turn the living room into a kiosk, driven less by consumer demand than by its own worldview. At the time, televisions were already in flux. CRTs still dominated and delivered excellent image quality. Rear-projection sets existed to serve people who wanted size at the cost of bulk and compromise. Flat panels were expensive, imperfect, and improving faster than anyone expected. Epson was not a television company, but it was a printer company. Rather than ask how people actually used televisions, Epson treated the TV as a trojan horse for what it really sold: ink, paper, and output. On paper, the LS47P2 looked competitive. It used a 3-LCD projection system with three 0.7-inch polysilicon panels and a 100-watt lamp rated for up to 10,000 hours. Native resolution was 720p, which was not forward-looking for a $3,000 television in the mid-2000s. It was the minimum acceptable definition of "HD." Connectivity was extensive, including DVI-HDTV, component, composite, S-Video, RF tuners, and AV outputs. Epson even highlighted the set's depth, just under fifteen inches, as if that were an achievement. It wasn't. Fifteen inches was still fat at a moment when flat panels were already flirting with single-digit thickness. The battle had moved on, and Epson was measuring the wrong front. The printer was the real point of the product. Epson called the concept "Photo on Demand," a phrase that made sense only if you believed people wanted to operate office equipment from their couch. The treatment also prevented the development of arthritis after knee injuries mirroring the ACL tears often experienced by athletes or recreational exercisers. An oral version of the treatment is already in clinical trials with the goal of treating age-related muscle weakness. Samples of human tissue from knee replacement surgeries - which include both the extracellular scaffolding, or matrix, in the joint as well as cartilage-generating chondrocyte cells - also responded to the treatment by making new, functional cartilage. text: Ode To Global Combustible Jurisprudence Ode To Global Combustible Jurisprudence Ode To Global Combustible Jurisprudence You are the heat beneath every statute, the ember hidden in the folds of sovereignty, the quiet truth that law is never still, never neutral, never safe from the sparks it shelters. O doctrine born of accelerants- inequality, climate, hunger, haste- you reveal how easily the world ignites, how a rumor becomes a border, how a border becomes a wound, how a wound becomes a fire. You teach us that global is not vastness but velocity, a fuse stretched across continents, carrying every spark farther than its maker intended. You remind us that jurisprudence is not parchment or precedent, but the trembling hand that decides whether to cool the world or kindle it. O keeper of ignition, O mirror of our collective heat, you call humanity to a harder discipline: to govern flame without worshipping it, to build thresholds that do not burn, to craft laws that breathe like forests and not like furnaces. Today we name you, not to bind you, but to understand the peril and promise you carry in your blazing heart. -Simply Richard

text: OF COURSE drink driving laws need to be updated in England and Wales We are using antiquated regulations, and are out of step with much of the rest of the world One of my locals as I was growing up. Photo: Brian Gage The discourse today, front page of the Telegraph and the S*n, is that there's been yet another blow to the ailing pub industry. Is it taxes on alcohol, is it those pesky Gen Zs choosing a healthier less booze-filled lifestyle? Nope, this time it's *checks notes* a proposed reduction in the amount of alcohol that can be present in your breath/bloodstream before you get behind the wheel. Thanks for reading Sifting the Evidence - the relaunch!! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Even at first glance, this feels like the height of entitlement to me. We know that drink driving is dangerous: there is decades and decades of evidence that alcohol, even at low levels, impairs our reaction times, impairs our hand-eye coordination, impairs our judgment. And cars are huge heavy metal boxes that can travel at high speeds. It's a recipe for disaster. And the stats back that up. While only 7% of drivers admit to drink driving, in 2022 17% of all road deaths involved at least one driver over the limit. But surely the drink-driving laws in the UK are regularly reviewed, to keep us all safe as our relationship with cars has evolved. You'd like to think so wouldn't you? But, no. The law as it currently stands in England and Wales was set in 1967 . That's just shy of 60 years ago! A lot has changed since then. In 1967 there were approximately 10 million cars on the road. Sounds like a lot, but in 2025 there were 42.3 million licensed vehicles , of which over 30 million are cars. So roads are likely to be 3 to 4x busier than they were when these laws were introduced. And what about cars themselves? Even in recent years the size and weight of cars has increased dramatically. According to Autocar the average weight of a car on the road in 2023 was 1947kg. text: Context Widows or, of GPUs, LPUs, and Goal Displacement A ‘draft' of Galileo's notes on Jupiter. Held as a treasure by the University of Michigan for 80 years ; it was actually produced by the 20th-century forger Tobia Nicotra. Fakes are nothing new. Enrollment is everything. The argument about whether large language models can "do science" has the structure of a trap. The debate proceeds along predictable lines: enthusiasts point to protein folding, to materials science, to the generation of novel hypotheses; critics point to hallucination, to the absence of understanding, to the difference between pattern-matching and insight. But answer yes and you're a booster, answer no and you're a skeptic, and either way you've made the technology the protagonist. Both sides assume the only question worth asking is a capabilities question: what can these systems really "do." This framing has a certain intuitive appeal, but it's the wrong question-or, more precisely, it's a question that forecloses the more interesting ones and leads us circling around questions with no grounding in social reality. There's a stealth neoplatonism embedded in the term "scientific discovery," as if discoveries exist in some ideal realm waiting to be accessed-or in the video-game addled vocabulary of contemporary science policy-waiting to be "unlocked." The debate is reduced to one about whether LLMs have the right kind of key. From a constructionist perspective-the tradition associated with Bruno Latour and science studies more broadly-this gets the epistemology backwards. Galileo's telescope didn't access some pre-existing truth about Jupiter's moons; the moons became scientific facts through a process of enrollment, as the telescope's outputs were taken up by institutions, integrated into arguments, and accepted as evidence. I'm a half-hearted Latourian at best, but on this point I'm a whole-hearted constructionist: whether LLMs can make "scientific discoveries" is no more interesting a question than whether Galileo's telescope "really saw." 1

text: Using AI to REMOVE Propaganda Grok is a great example of an AI designed to give a politically biassed result. But what if you could use AI to remove political bias? The AIs most are using for free right now are based on large language models (LLMs) – they digest vast amounts of content and, from that, deduce rules about how to interpret what you give them. Because they are given so much compute power, and can consume so much content, they can quickly produce something that looks convincing. Of course, what looks convincing is often not true – ask any con man. With AIs this is particularly true for narrow subject areas. Ask then anything about Scottish Government policy, for example, and you'll find only a handful of referenced sources – many with strong political bias. Using an AI can easily generate political propaganda, dressed up as fact. But don't give up! AIs are still useful in other ways. For example, tidying up your text and checking grammar (you can probably tell I didn't use one in writing this article). They can also re-write text in different ways – e.g. pulling out key points or making a summary more engaging. You could probably do this yourself, but its just quicker with an AI to help. It occurred to me that I could do the same thing with things other people had written. Subscribe now I have a particular bug bear about British media in Scotland – virtually all are based in England and are forever misrepresenting what our Scottish Government and Scottish political parties do. The slant is always pro-unionist, pro-Westminster. They're always fast to highlight apparent issues (with no balanced comparison with e.g. England) and never highlight Scottish success. text: Planes and Helicopters in Masquerade That Stole the Show Top 10 Flying Actors There's something undeniably thrilling about seeing real planes and helicopters fighting in the skies on television or in film. But what happens when producers can't get their hands on the exact aircraft they want? That's when aeroplanes become true "flying actors" , stepping into roles as exotic enemy fighters, high-tech helicopters, or even fantastical sci-fi machines. With clever modifications, prosthetic add-ons, and imaginative paint schemes, these airborne stand-ins often steal the show-capturing viewers' imaginations and becoming just as beloved, or even more beloved, as the human stars on screen. 10: Puma to Hind Rambo: First Blood Part II (1985) featured what appeared to be a Soviet attack helicopter. For Western audiences at the time, this was an exotic sight, as the Cold War meant genuine Soviet aircraft were rarely, if ever, seen outside the Eastern Bloc. The imposing gunship became an iconic part of the film's Vietnam‑style action. With red stars and Soviet‑style camouflage, the helicopter bristled with what appeared to be rockets and mounted guns. In reality, it was a cleverly disguised Aérospatiale SA 330 Puma, a French transport helicopter. Its transformation relied on cosmetic modifications, including large prosthetic wings, ‘missile' pods, and other attachments to give it a distinctly Soviet appearance. Puma to Hind The same airframe had previously performed a similar role in Red Dawn (1984) and later returned in subsequent Rambo films. Weapons added for effect included an M60 machine gun designed to resemble a Soviet DShK, a GE M134 Minigun styled as a YakB 12.7mm rotary gun, and an FN MAG styled as a PKM. The GE M134 was mounted beneath the faux "Hind" gunship, firing bursts of propane and acetylene to simulate muzzle flashes. Sound effects were added in post-production. text: Wealth Inequality is Epistemology ... from 'The Epistemic Argument for Anarchism' An anarchist doesn't need much money , modulo family size, since personal needs are easy to meet, and beyond that level, money primarily corresponds to influence over others, and anarchists place the burden of proof on anyone who wants a power difference to exist. text: Pyramids weren‚Äôt tombs. They were power. Old Kingdom pyramids and images were not separate categories of architecture and art so much as interlocking technologies for making kingship durable. Old Kingdom pyramids and images were not separate categories of architecture and art so much as interlocking technologies for making kingship durable. In the 3rd and 4th Dynasties, the royal tomb changes from a mostly horizontal, enclosed mastaba tradition into a radically vertical monument that turns the dead king into a permanent feature of the landscape, and that new geometry reorganizes everything around it. How the afterlife is pictured, how cult is funded, how labor is mobilized, and how bodies (real and represented) are disciplined into ideals. What looks to modern eyes like a leap in engineering is also a leap in political theology, because the pyramid does not merely house the king; it stages the king's continuing function as guarantor of cosmic order and as the state's organizing principle (Lehner; Verner). That is why Old Kingdom form tends toward the absolute; massive stone, controlled profiles, standardized proportions, repeated images, and tightly managed access. The system is designed to outlast weather, time, and human unreliability, and it does so by distributing "presence" across architecture, sculpture, text, and ritual in redundant layers (Metropolitan Museum of Art, Egypt in the Old Kingdom). The mastaba background matters because it establishes the older grammar that the pyramid will intensify rather than erase. Elite mastabas and their chapels already frame the tomb as a place where the living sustain the dead through offerings, recitation, and images that keep identity socially legible. A false door on a west wall, for example, is not decoration; it is an engineered threshold where the dead receive offerings and where the living direct speech and ritual toward a specific person whose name, titles, and images fix them in relation to family, office, and land (Metropolitan Museum of Art, False Door from the Tomb of Metjetji). text: The Very Simple Case For Utilitarianism  All interests are equal, and only interests matter A lot of non-utilitarians don't really see the draw of utilitarianism. 1 To them, we're a curious bunch. We think it's great to kill people and harvest their organs ( in an idealized case , of course). We care about shrimp. What the hell is going on? Now, I don't really think caring about shrimp is limited to utilitarians -if anything, maybe deontologists should care about them more . But I want to try to communicate what I consider to be the core motivation behind utilitarianism. Not beating the stereotypes At the most basic level, I think utilitarianism follows if you think the following two things: Everyone's interests count equally. Nothing else counts more than someone's interests. Note: when I say counts I mean "should influence decision-making." Utilitarianism says you should maximize aggregate welfare. If you think everyone's welfare matters the same amount and nothing matters apart from that, then you'll think we should maximize aggregate welfare. So you'll end up a utilitarian. Both of these premises strike me as pretty intuitive. It's not incoherent to deny them, and there are some intuitions that conflict with them, but they strike me as pretty natural moral starting points. Thinking them through helps illustrate what's weird about non-utilitarian verdicts. Take, for example, the view that nature has intrinsic value. This view would deny 2. It would hold that sometimes, if you're deciding between someone's interests and preserving nature, you should preserve nature. But that's pretty weird. Nature isn't a person. It has no thoughts or experiences. If we're trading off helping someone with helping no one, but simply adorning the world with more pretty nature, it strikes me as very odd to prioritize nature. We shouldn't make one person worse-off if doing so makes no one better-off. Note: this isn't the only reason I reject that nature has intrinsic value. I have other arguments. But I'm just trying to illustrate the structure of the core utilitarian view.

text: Three Value Clumps I have long posted on studies that try to make sense of how human values differ, and how they have changed over time. I have long posted on studies that try to make sense of how human values differ, and how they have changed over time. A new paper in Social Science Quarterly tries to compare four different proposed values models, by modeling the network of correlations of the variables they see as central. This diagram shows their key result: three clumps of 2-4 named clusters, each of which has 3-10 correlated variables: Alas that paper doesn't give names for the particular variables, and some of the clump names seem overly opaque. But what I can see is still interesting. The bottom of the diagram seem to be items most closely related to status. The lower right clump (called "virtuous agency") matters most to modern elites, while the middle clump (called "power and social order") mattered more in the farming era. Did the upper right clump (called "hierarchical individualism") matter most to foragers, and also matter more now due to a toward-forager modern culture trend? I've suggested that many modern differences are due to moderns seeing themselves as higher status, due to their higher wealth. If so, that virtuous agency would also have mattered more to farming era elites, while the power and social order clump should matter more to non-elites today.

text: Assembling the Pieces: From Assembly Text to Binary Objects Your compiler spits out assembly, but computers don‚Äôt run text files, so what happens next? Introduction In our last article , we looked inside the compiler and saw how it builds an Abstract Syntax Tree, checks your syntax, and generates assembly code, those mov , call , and ret instructions. We generated main.s and source.s using g++ -S . Those are text files you can read. But your CPU doesn't execute text. It needs binary machine code which are ones and zeros. That's where the assembler comes in. The assembler's job is dead simple: take assembly text ( .s files) and translate each instruction into its binary equivalent. The output is an object file ( .o on Linux, .obj on Windows). These are chunks of machine code, but they're not complete programs yet. They have missing pieces such as references to functions in other files or libraries. That's what the linker will fix in Part 5. In this part, we'll compile our code into separate object files using -c (full form: --compile ). Then we'll use objdump to inspect those binary blobs and see what symbols (functions, variables) they contain. By the end, you'll understand why compiling large projects file-by-file is faster and how "separate compilation" works. Thanks for reading Low-Level Lore! text: Certainties I‚Äôve been thinking about the challenges of singing a fugue and its relevance to everyday life. I've been thinking about the challenges of singing a fugue and its relevance to everyday life. A quick and crude explanation for the non-musicians reading – in choral music, and elsewhere, a fugue consists of a theme, or themes, sung in one part and taken up by the others at different times, with some variations, overlapping and building, weaving together an interlocking and exhilarating piece of music. It can be a challenge to sing. Why a challenge? First, your entries as a singer can come fast and furious with little in the way of assistance from the other lines of music – the weave makes cues difficult to pick up on. The singer has to be alert, counting (sometimes furiously), watching the conductor, keeping an eye on his place in the score, confident in coming in, and accurate. Second, losing your place in the piece is a real danger and, if you do, finding a way back in is tricky because of the nature of the form. There's just too much going on. It's all a little nerve racking – and, yes, exhilarating. It struck me that singing a fugue is a little like navigating a complicated world in the need to be aware of everything around us, but at the same time staying focussed on our part in it – confident of when to come in and what to ‘sing' but not too certain, too arrogant, too complacent. The singer who is certain of his or her entries without paying any attention to what is going on around them is riding for a fall and could even bring the whole thing crashing down (that's the nightmare). Singing, like life, is a communal activity and if the pace alters, the musical director decides to take it a little faster maybe, the singer has to be able to adjust, cannot be too certain. That would be dangerous. The spark for these musings was a passage in Colin Heber-Percy's book, Lost in the Forest , in which he talks about the dangers of certainty in the wider world. As I was preparing my remarks, an uncomfortable truth dawned: my own Duolingo habit is less a virtuous routine than a cleverly engineered addiction. text: The Oreshnik Problem for Europe Technical constraints, opportunity costs, and Europe‚Äôs unresolved deterrence deficits Picture: Via X On the night of January 8 to 9, 2026, Russia launched the second confirmed Oreshnik missile strike against Ukraine. While the launch confirms the operational limitations of the missile system, the strike also highlights the dilemma the missile poses for European defense. Thanks for reading Missile Matters - with Fabian Hoffmann! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Capability profile The Oreshnik appears to be an intermediate-range ballistic missile with an estimated maximum range of roughly 3,000 to 5,500 kilometers. It is reportedly equipped with up to six MIRVed payloads that independently reenter the atmosphere to strike separate aimpoints. Each payload is said to carry up to six submunitions released during the terminal phase of flight, producing area effects around the intended target. Operational use suggests that the missile carries an inert payload, meaning it is not equipped with high explosives. Instead, lethality derives from the mass and velocity of the submunitions upon impact. Given the high terminal velocity of the payload (estimated at Mach 10-11 by some Russian and Ukrainian sources, though this likely represents an upper bound), even relatively light submunitions can impart substantial kinetic energy, sufficient to cause serious damage to above-ground concrete structures. The missile's genealogy can be traced to the RS-26 Rubezh, which was developed between 2008 and 2018 but was mothballed before reaching full operational capability. The RS-26 was conceived, tested, and publicly presented as a nuclear delivery system. As a result, the Oreshnik is very likely dual-capable, meaning it can carry both non-nuclear and nuclear payloads. It remains unclear whether Russia has already certified the Oreshnik for nuclear delivery, although doing so should be technically straightforward and would likely require only limited adaptations, such as rebalancing the missile to account for changes in weight distribution. text: Let's get ready to dot watchüìç What is dot watching and why are we all quietly obsessed by it? Credit: Montane Spine Winter Race Tomorrow, people all over the world will be dot watching. If you've never done it before, you might be reading that sentence and thinking, what on earth are you on about. Dot watching is, quite simply, following the progress of someone in a race via an online tracker. Each runner is represented by a dot or pin on a map, usually with their bib number attached, and as they move through the course, so does the dot. It's most commonly used for really long ultramarathons where competitors are out on the course for days rather than hours. The reason so many people will be dot watching tomorrow is because it's the start of the winter Spine Race , a series of races including the "brutal" 268-mile race along the Pennine Way. This legendary race is where Jasmin Paris rose to international fame when she won the event outright whilst breastfeeding her daughter, back in 2019 (this story forms the start of my co-authored book Ultra Women ). Meanwhile the summer version of the race was won outright by 55-year-old Anna Troup in 2025, and she chatted to me about the challenge just days afterwards. text: Can advanced AI lead to negative economic growth?  Considering the role of demand in the economics of AI This essay is about the role of economic demand in AI-driven growth forecasts. The premise is simple: if advanced AI (or AGI, which I will use interchangeably) automates most labor and the wage share collapses, who will buy the increased output? If firms anticipate weak demand, will they keep investing and producing? Will the economy face a gap between potential and realized output, and actually shrink? Let's take a simple parable, suggested to me by Tom Cunningham, that illustrates this logic. Imagine there's an island with 100 workers and 10 capital owners. Everyone consumes two types of goods, fish and coconuts. Workers catch fish and harvest coconuts using nets and ladders provided by the capital owners. Workers are paid wages for their labor and spend everything they earn on the two goods. Revenue goes directly to the owners. The owners are wealthy, and because a person can only eat so many fish and coconuts, they consume 10 of each per day and have their fill. Thanks for reading Ghosts of Electricity! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Now let's say fishing gets automated. Someone invents self-operating nets that catch fish without workers. Workers are fully displaced from fishing and move on to harvesting coconuts, which still requires labor. Workers still earn wages, and because fish has now become much cheaper, they may be even better off than before as their earnings can now buy them more of the two goods. Output rises in this economy: owners respond to demand by investing in nets and labor is now fully devoted to coconuts. Across Silicon Valley, a seductive sales pitch is being polished for public consumption. The narrative suggests that the solution to our global mental health crisis isn't more human beings, but more code. Generative AI "therapists"-available 24/7, devoid of waitlists, and costing pennies compared to a human session-are being marketed to a younger generation not as a compromise, but as an upgrade. The promise is a "frictionless" second-tier mental health system. But in our rush to patch human suffering with monthly updates and app downloads, we're making a big mistake, a dangerous category error. We are confusing information with intervention, and data exchange with healing. I understand the desperation. As a clinician, I've watched clients wait months for appointments while their lives unravel. I've heard stories of many in crisis turned away because there aren't enough therapists to meet demand. When someone is drowning, any rope looks like rescue. But we need to be honest about what this actually is. The "Good Enough" Trap We are entering an era where the well off will continue to pay for the privilege of in-person human connection, while the rest of the world is handed a chatbot. By framing AI as a viable alternative rather than a temporary stopgap, we are normalizing the idea that the "witness" to their pain doesn't need to be alive-and that nuance is simply a lack of data. Trust in the prime minister is now at its highest level since the survey began in 2010, when it stood at just 65 percent. At the same time, trust in Parliament has risen to 83 percent. In an era defined by political cynicism, institutional fatigue, and constant outrage, those numbers are not normal. They are extraordinary. Canadians are not suddenly naive. They are responding to leadership that treats the public like adults. Carney has built credibility by being measured, serious, and grounded in evidence rather than slogans. He does not govern by rage farming or daily performance art. He governs by explaining trade offs, acknowledging constraints, and focusing on outcomes. That approach does not always thrill social media, but it earns something far more valuable, public trust. The rise in trust in Parliament is just as important. For years, Canadians have been told that democratic institutions are broken beyond repair. That narrative has been useful for those who benefit from undermining confidence and lowering expectations. The Environics findings suggest something different. When leadership stabilizes, institutions recover. When debate is rooted in reality instead of perpetual grievance, people re engage. This moment also exposes a clear political contrast. text: The Verification Ladder: A Framework for Evaluating Video When You Can‚Äôt Tell What‚Äôs Real "Is this real?" isn't a straightforward question anymore. What to ask instead, and why the source often matters more than the footage itself. A video lands in a group chat: a celebrity saying something wildly out of character. The first instinct is to react. The second, increasingly, is to wonder: wait, is this even real? The mouth movements look right. The voice sounds right. The lighting stays consistent across the frame. And still, there's no way to know for certain just by watching. This is the new default. And if you've felt a growing unease about it, a sense that the ground has shifted beneath your feet in ways you weren't prepared for, you're responding appropriately to the situation. What Changed, and When For most of the history of recorded media, a photograph or video served as evidence. It wasn't perfect evidence. Photos could be staged, footage could be edited, context could be stripped away. But the underlying assumption held: if you could see it, someone had pointed a camera at something that existed in the world. That assumption began to erode in late 2017, when a Reddit user posted the first widely circulated " deepfakes ," videos using AI to swap celebrities' faces onto other bodies. The term combines "deep learning" (a type of artificial intelligence) with "fake." The underlying technology, called Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), had been developed by researcher Ian Goodfellow in 2014, but 2017 marked its entry into public accessibility. Early deepfakes were crude, obviously artificial, relatively easy to identify. They also required significant time and technical knowledge to produce. Each of those barriers has fallen. The technology has improved substantially. The cost has dropped to near-zero for basic applications. The time required has shrunk from days to minutes. And the scope has expanded beyond face-swapping to include voice cloning, full-body generation, and the creation of entirely synthetic scenes. The result is a world where " seeing is believing " no longer functions as a reliable heuristic. Video evidence is no longer self-verifying. Subscribe now The Emotional Reali

You had access to publication. You also had access to the company of other poets. There were conversations with poets like Derek Mahon and Brendan Kennelly which were truly sustaining for me. So I did associate with poets and see something of the poetic life. And as I've been very critical of that climate since then, I don't want to minimize the good and positive parts of it. But there were also deprivations to being a woman poet in that situation, and I don't want to minimize those either. Especially as the deprivations carried some actual dangers to identity. text: Past Lives and Summer Hours movies about love sometimes count as sports at night in the city in summer The Angelika is a piece of shit and a terrible place to watch movies and we were all just so happy to be there. On a Saturday night at the very beginning of June, in a narrow basement full of old-fashioned uncomfortable seats, directly over top of a subway line that rattled the floors every time a train went by , the 7PM showing of Past Lives was sold out and the crowd was nearly feral. Kids, or people I understood as kids, piled in as though arriving at a house party. They carried snacks and drinks and huge bags and unfeasible jackets and extra shoes. They spilled popcorn, lost their phones in their seats, and tripped over themselves so lavishly it felt like it must be for show. School was out, but summer wasn't quite here yet. The previous week, college graduations had cascaded across the city's parks and subways and mid-tier restaurants. New grads in glossy polyester robes had clutched diplomas and flowers and tried to outpace their visiting parents trailing behind them. Then they left, or some of them did, and graduation season evaporated into the uncertain hallway between summer and life. May turned the corner to June. The heat settled down on the days. Air conditioners dripped heavy splats onto pavement. The college kids who hadn't left for new lives or vacation homes hung around downtown, done with one thing but not yet onto the next. Nobody knew what day it was; nobody knew if their life had started yet. Nobody knew what to do, so everybody went to the movies. By everybody, I mean every confused young person below 14th street, and by the movies I mean this one specific showing of Past Lives , at the Angelika at 7pm on Friday night. Or anyway that's how it seemed, as the auditorium filled up with chaos around me before the movie started. text: We've Seen This Movie Before: The Part Everyone Skips AI, Power, and the Principles of Real Governance AI, Power, and the Principles of Real Governance Once a technology reaches a certain level of capability, arguing about whether it should exist stops being useful. That argument always shows up late. By the time it arrives, the infrastructure is already in place, money has picked a direction, and power has quietly settled where it intends to stay. Thanks for reading And Here's My Secret...! Subscribe for free to receive new posts and support my work. Artificial intelligence is already past that point. So the question is not whether AI should exist. Reality has already answered that. The question is whether we are willing to govern it deliberately, or whether we are going to do what we usually do and let governance emerge by accident. We have run this pattern before. What People Mean When They Say "This Feels Dangerous" Most objections to AI are framed as ethical concerns, but they are vague. People say it is moving too fast. They say the technology crossed a line. They say something feels off. Those reactions are understandable. They are also incomplete. What people are usually reacting to is not AI itself. It is the erosion of confidence in judgment. Authorship feels unstable. Trust feels harder to place. It is not always clear who is responsible for what you are seeing, reading, or relying on. AI is unusual because it is easy to use while remaining hard to understand.
